Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the names of all those on the Sheffield Stronger Together Leadership Group (first meeting 5th November and as reported at Strategy & Resources 20th November).  As this is apparently a ‘partnership group’ not ‘led’ by the council (although apparently chaired by the Leader) I recognise that the council may try to say it does not ‘own’ this data.  In this case, however, I simply request the names of all those attending this meeting which was attended by council members on behalf of residents and voters.
(Once again) I find it astounding that our public representatives (presumably supported by officers), in participating in a major initiative about ‘leading’ the city - for and on behalf of residents/voters has not seen fit to be wholly transparent about its running of the city and in anticipation of public interest.  This work comes out of the ‘city goals’ work which our council is claiming is somehow ‘owned’ by all in the city!  Yet the elite group now apparently leading this work is, at the outset, hidden!
I would also like to know:
- the specific governance arrangements in place for the partnership of ‘leaders’
- where the minutes of the meetings will be publicly available, how the public can observe and participate directly (at all) in its work, and any other arrangements in place to enhance transparency and external accountability to citizens and communities.
Finally, the council has reported that the ‘transition team’ has put the ‘city leader’ group arrangements in place and I request information about how city leaders were selected (criteria etc), minutes of ‘transition team’ meetings since the publication of the city goals and, again, which I am assuming council members and/or officers were part of.
The ‘murkiness’ of transparency and accountability arrangements for partnership groups involving combinations of statutory, corporate/private, and third sector partners is a live issue across the country (and has been for many years now)  and so I imagine this has been a priority in discussions setting up the partnership, (and given SCC’s presentation of itself as a learning council).  It is nonetheless quite disturbing to be having to submit FOIs for basic information to meet very minimal democratic thresholds.
Thank you very much
Yours faithfully,
Ruth Hubbard

Dear Ruth Hubbard
Thank you for your request for information relating to the Sheffield
Stronger Together Leadership Group and City Goals, which we received on
25/11/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below.
We are attaching a response to all your questions, which we have
highlighted in purple at the start of each response.
Please note that we have used [R] in place of a small number of names or
personal information (i.e., when named people are taking annual leave).
The names of some of our staff, and some third parties, have been redacted
under section 40(2) of the Freedom of Information Act 2000. These are
personal data, and disclosure would contravene the data protection
principle under Article 5(1)(a) of the General Data Protection Regulation
that processing of personal data must be lawful, fair, and transparent.
These individuals played a facilitative role and had a reasonable
expectation of privacy. FOI is a “disclosure to the world” and it would
not be fair to them to publish their names.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see

for further details.
Kind Regards
